title: Easy Guide of Narita Express
description: The Narita Express, operated by JR East, is a premium train service connecting Narita Airport to downtown Tokyo, also known by its abbreviation N'E...

children.value:
The Narita Express, operated by JR East, is a premium train service connecting Narita Airport to downtown Tokyo, also known by its abbreviation N'EX.
Although originally intended for airport transportation, during peak commuting hours, trains bound for Tokyo city center and those bound for the airport during evening rush hours, also stop at high-demand commuter stations such as Narita, Sakura, Yotsukaido, and Chiba.
The routes can be broadly categorized into two: Shinjuku-bound and Ofuna-bound.

:
Trains departing from Narita Airport mostly run to Shinjuku Station, but during evening rush hours, two trains extend to Hachioji Station. Trains bound for Narita Airport depart from Shinjuku regardless of the time of day.

:
Both departure and arrival are to and from Ofuna Station.
Changed to only run up to Takao Station after March 2019.
Changed to only run up to Hachioji Station after March 2021.
Changed to depart from Shinjuku Station only after March 2024.
Since there's too much content to list all, I'll focus on the Narita Airport to Tokyo Station timetable.
Narita Airport Terminal 1 Station -> Tokyo Station
Weekday train schedule is as follows:
Weekend train schedules have many overlapping parts, so only the differences from weekday schedules are listed.
Trains 50 and 52 bound for Hachioji only run up to Shinjuku on weekends.
There are some trains departing exactly 1 minute earlier, but their arrival times are the same as weekdays, so there's no need to consider them differently.
The additional travel time to the remaining stops for both Shinjuku-bound and Afternoon-bound trains is as follows:
Tokyo Station -> Narita Airport Terminal 1 Station
On weekdays, the train schedule is as follows.
On weekends, the train schedule is as follows.

N'EX is characterized by combined operation, where two or more motorized vehicles are connected together.
Trains departing from Narita Airport are separated at Tokyo Station, and if you're sitting in the wrong car, you may end up at an unwanted destination.
Trains to Narita Airport also depart from Tokyo Station in a combined train. Trains from Ofuna arrive and wait first, then depart together when trains from Shinjuku arrive.

Of the total 12 cars, the first 6 cars are bound for Ofuna, and the last 6 cars are bound for Shinjuku.
Therefore, on the up line, cars 1 to 6 are bound for Ofuna, and cars 7 to 12 are bound for Shinjuku, while on the down line, cars 1 to 6 are bound for Shinjuku, and cars 7 to 12 are bound for Ofuna.
Fares and charges and where to buy them
Regular fares vary based on distance traveled. However, with the
pass, you can travel for a consistent fare of 5,000 yen, regardless of distance. To purchase this pass, the following conditions apply:
After using the first ticket, you must use the remaining tickets within 14 days.
Destinations towards Tokyo from Narita Airport Terminals 1, 2, and 3
Using N'EX TOKYO Round Trip Ticket

props.title: Convenience of N'EX Tokyo Round Trip Ticket

children.value:
When using the N'EX Tokyo round-trip ticket to travel between the airport and downtown, it's not necessary to use the same station for both legs of the journey.
In other words, it's possible to disembark at Tokyo Station and then travel from Shinjuku Station to Narita Airport.
On-site purchases can be made at the following locations located in Narita Airport Terminal 1 and Narita Airport Terminals 2 and 3.
JR East Japan Travel Service Centers
Reserved seat ticket vending machines equipped with passport readers
To make online reservations, use the

on the JR East Japan website.
Note that since the N'EX Tokyo Round Trip Ticket is a pass, you should reserve it through the pass purchase menu, not the ticket purchase menu.

: There is luggage compartment area space between the entrance and the cabin aisle, and each luggage shelf is equipped with a dial lock.
If you're still uneasy about leaving your luggage in a place where it's out of sight, you can also place it on the footrest due to the spacious seat spacing.

: Cars 1 and 7 have standard restrooms, while cars 6 and 12 have large restrooms that accommodate wheelchairs.
Each restroom is equipped with a baby bed and a baby seat.
: Power outlets are available at the front of every seat armrest, allowing you to charge your smartphone or use your laptop.
: After boarding the N'EX, as long as you don't exit through the ticket gate along the way, you can get off at any JR East Japan station shown on the route map without additional charge.
If not that station, not much benefit

: The N'EX is the most expensive transportation option between Narita Airport and downtown Tokyo, but it's also not the fastest.
Therefore, if Tokyo Station, Shibuya Station, Shinjuku Station, and other stations where the N'EX stops are your origin or destination, you'll benefit from not having to transfer, but if not, there are better alternatives.

props.alt: Slow N'EX due to too long and sharp turns in the railroad tracks

title: A must when traveling abroad! Tips for comparing mobile internet options: USIM Â· eSIM Â· Pocket Wi-Fi and Data roaming
description: When it comes to using mobile internet abroad, there are several options to consider: eSIM, USIM, pocket Wi-Fi, and data roaming. Each option has its own adv...

children.value: This article is based on mobile data plans in South Korea.

When it comes to using mobile internet abroad, there are several options to consider: eSIM, USIM, pocket Wi-Fi, and data roaming.
Each option has its own advantages and disadvantages, and their strengths complement each other, making it challenging to determine an absolute best choice.
The decision often depends on individual preferences regarding convenience, speed, and price.

In this article, we will explore the pros and cons of each option and compare them in terms of convenience, speed, and price.
To facilitate the price comparison, let's assume a

USIM is a physical SIM card that allows you to use the local carrier's SIM card in the country you are traveling to,
similar to how you would use a locally activated service from the carrier.
Pros: It offers fast and cost-effective service as it directly utilizes the local carrier's network.

Cons: SIM replacement might be cumbersome, and caution is needed to prevent loss or damage.
Additionally, you won't receive calls or texts on your original number.

props.title: Delivery fee included in the price

children.value: It was calculated including the delivery fee because the delivery fee is added both when sending it to the airport terminal and when receiving it by courier.
eSIM, or embedded SIM, is a digital form of SIM that is built into the device. Like USIM, it utilizes the local carrier's network, providing fast connectivity.

Pros: It can be used in dual SIM mode alongside your existing USIM.
Calls and texts use your home carrier, while data uses the local carrier.
Cons: It's a relatively newer technology, and not all smartphones support eSIM.
For SKT users, connecting to data roaming or Wi-Fi abroad with a Korean SIM card
activates the T Phone app in baro mode

.
During this mode, you can use your Korean number for calls and texts for
free, especially when connected to Wi-Fi
Also known as a mobile router, it's simply a

that you can take with you.
It is relatively slower than USIM or eSIM as it relies on the local carrier through the home carrier.
Pros: It can connect multiple devices simultaneously and is the most economical option for multiple users.
Cons: Handling, return, damage, and monitoring battery levels can be cumbersome.
One free day for 3 or more days of usage (excluding Japan/Asia).
Long-term discounts applied for 6 days or more.

A service that allows travelers to use the local carrier's network through a partnership with the traveler's home carrier.
No need to purchase or install a SIM card separately.
Pros: Convenient as you can use your smartphone without additional setup.
Cons: Relatively expensive compared to other options.
Free calls with baro calls, no data deduction.

The listed products are fixed with a certain number of days, with KT offering 5 days and U+ offering 3 days.
If you need to use roaming for more than the fixed duration, you will have to opt for a relatively more expensive product that allows you to specify the number of days.
Below is a list of products configured with the cheapest options.
: eSIM > USIM > Pocket Wi-Fi > Data Roaming
: Pocket Wi-Fi > eSIM > USIM > Data Roaming
Data Roaming > USIM > eSIM > Pocket Wi-Fi
USIM = eSIM > Data Roaming >= Pocket Wi-Fi
